questions.text: Which mode of transmission of HIV has the maximum risk of transmission?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Blood transfusion has the maximum risk of transmission.
  • HIV is mainly spread through sexual contact, blood exposure, and mother-to-child transmission.
  • Sexual transmission is the most common route globally, with heterosexual transmission dominating in developing countries and male-to-male transmission in many developed regions.
  • However, the efficiency of heterosexual transmission is generally low, especially in the absence of genital ulcers and high viral loads.
  • Seminal and vaginal fluids contain HIV, and the risk increases with conditions like genital inflammation and ulcerative STIs.
  • Receptive anal intercourse carries the highest sexual transmission risk due to the thin and fragile nature of rectal mucosa and the potential for trauma.
  • Several cofactors influence transmission, including viral load, which is the primary determinant of infectivity. High plasma HIV RNA levels increase the likelihood of transmission, while effective antiretroviral therapy (ART) reduces it significantly.
  • When HIV is undetectable in the blood due to ART, the risk of sexual transmission becomes virtually zero: a concept widely known as "U=U" (Undetectable = Untransmittable).
  • Male circumcision also reduces HIV acquisition, particularly in heterosexual men, likely due to decreased exposure of target immune cells in the foreskin and reduced risk of ulcerative STIs.
  • Injection drug use presents a substantial risk, especially with shared needles or paraphernalia, as does transfusion of infected blood, which carries the highest per-act risk. (Options A, C, and D ruled out)
  • However, modern screening has nearly eliminated transfusion-related transmission in countries with advanced healthcare systems.
  • Occupational exposure, particularly among healthcare workers who sustain needlestick injuries or mucosal contact with infected fluids, has a small but documented risk. The use of postexposure prophylaxis (PEP) in these cases significantly lowers this risk.
  • Mother-to-child transmission can occur during pregnancy, delivery, or breastfeeding. The risk is closely linked to maternal viral load and ART during pregnancy and avoidance of breastfeeding where alternatives are safe can reduce this risk substantially.

questions.text: Which of the HIV virus's three structural genes encodes the P24 antigen, which is commonly detected in diagnostic tests to confirm the infection?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The HIV virion exhibits an icosahedral shape with many external surface spikes. These spikes are composed of the envelope proteins gp120 and gp41.
  • The envelope exists as a trimeric heterodimer, and the virus buds from the host cell surface, incorporating host proteins into its lipid bilayer during this process.
  • Although retroviruses possess a positive-sense RNA genome, they lack the machinery to replicate this RNA directly in the cytoplasm.
  • Instead, each virion contains two copies of the RNA genome, two transfer RNA (tRNA) molecules, and an RNA-dependent DNA polymerase known as reverse transcriptase.
  • The tRNA acts as a primer for generating a circular complementary DNA (cDNA) copy of the viral RNA. This cDNA is produced in the cytoplasm and then transported to the nucleus, where it becomes integrated into the host cell's chromatin.
  • Once integrated, the viral genome behaves like a cellular gene. Promoters located at both ends of the inserted viral DNA enhance its transcription by the host cell, producing full-length RNA transcripts that serve as new viral genomes.
  • Additionally, alternative splicing of these transcripts gives rise to various individual mRNAs.
  • The replication process begins when the viral gp120 protein binds with high specificity to CD4 receptors, mainly on T-helper lymphocytes. This binding triggers a conformational change, enabling interaction with one of the two co-receptors, CCR5 or CXCR4, which facilitates viral entry into the host cell.
  • The viral gp41 protein aids in fusion with the host membrane, allowing the viral core to enter the cytoplasm. Uncoating follows, forming the preintegration complex containing viral RNA, enzymes, and accessory proteins.
  • Reverse transcription occurs, converting viral RNA to DNA. This newly synthesized DNA integrates into the host genome via the viral integrase enzyme, targeting active transcription regions.

The replication cycle of HIV is illustrated in the image below.

  • The HIV genome consists of genes encoding structural proteins (gag), enzymes (pol), and envelope glycoproteins (env).
  • The gag gene forms the core proteins such as p24, pol encodes reverse transcriptase, integrase, and protease, while env encodes gp120 and gp41. (Options B, C, and D ruled out)

questions.text:
Select the correct structural features of Human immunodeficiency virus
1. Icosahedral symmetry
2. Helical symmetry
3. Complex symmetry
4. Enveloped
5. Non enveloped
6. 2 copies of ssRNA
7. 3 copies ssRNA
8. Segmented
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The Human immunodeficiency virus is an enveloped virus with icosahedral symmetry and the genome is composed of two copies of linear, positive-sense, single-stranded RNA.
  • Human Immunodeficiency Virus (HIV) belongs to the Lentivirus genus within the Retroviridae
  • The Retroviridae family is categorized into seven genera including Deltaretrovirus to which human T-lymphotropic viruses (HTLV) belongs and Lentivirus which encompasses HIV.
  • HIV is an enveloped virus with an icosahedral capsid, cylindrical core and a diploid genome consisting of two copies of linear, positive-sense single-stranded RNA. (Options A, C, and D ruled out)
  • The genome includes the standard retroviral genes gag, pol, and env, as well as several accessory genes, making it more genetically complex than oncogenic retroviruses such as HTLV.
  • HIV uses reverse transcriptase to convert its RNA into DNA, which integrates into the host genome, forming a provirus. The integrated proviral DNA then serves as a template for viral replication. Viral particles mature by budding from the host cell membrane.
  • HIV primarily targets cells of the immune system, particularly macrophages and T lymphocytes, and causes a chronic, slowly progressive immunodeficiency.
  • The virus is non-oncogenic but cytocidal. Proviruses remain permanently integrated, and their expression is limited in certain cells in vivo.
  • HIV exhibits marked genetic variability, which contributes to its ability to escape immune detection and complicates vaccine development.
  • There are two major types of HIV: HIV-1 and HIV-2. HIV-1 is more prevalent globally and is divided into three groups (M, N, O).
  • Group M is the most widespread and includes at least 11 subtypes, which differ genetically but not in pathogenesis.
  • HIV-2 is genetically closer to simian viruses found in sooty mangabeys. HIV-1 and HIV-2 differ by over 50% in nucleotide sequence.
  • Primate lentiviruses, including HIV, use CD4 as a primary receptor and require a second coreceptor for entry.
  • The coreceptor facilitates membrane fusion by interacting with the viral gp41
  • The coreceptors include chemokine receptors such as CCR5 (used by macrophage-tropic strains) and CXCR4 (used by lymphocyte-tropic strains)
  • Individuals with CCR5 gene deletions may be resistant to HIV infection or experience slower disease progression.
  • Maraviroc is an antiretroviral medication which functions by preventing the virus from entering human cells, specifically by inhibiting its interaction with the CCR5 co-receptor.
  • The pathogenesis of HIV includes the depletion of CD4+ T cells, which severely impairs the immune system.

questions.text: Scientists studying the HIV virus in the laboratory observe that it undergoes frequent mutations, leading to significant genetic variability. Which gene of the HIV virus is primarily responsible for this high mutation rate?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • HIV is a diploid virus enclosed in an envelope, featuring an icosahedral capsid and a cylindrical core.
  • Its genome is made up of two identical strands of linear, positive-sense single-stranded RNA.
  • The viral genome carries the typical retroviral genes such as gag, pol, and env along with multiple accessory genes, making it more genetically intricate than oncogenic retroviruses like HTLV.
  • HIV produces its proteins initially as large precursor polyproteins: Gag-Pol - Pr160, Gag - Pr55, and Env - gp160, which must be enzymatically processed to form the mature viral components.
  • The viral protease cleaves Gag-Pol and Gag into smaller, functional proteins, while the Env polyprotein is processed by a host cell protease, resulting in the formation of gp120 and

Some of the genes and proteins encoded by them are given in the table below.

  • Within an infected person, there exists a diverse array of viral genetic variants known as quasispecies.
  • This diversity results from the virus's rapid replication and the error-prone nature of its reverse transcriptase enzyme.
  • The highest variability among different HIV strains is seen in the env gene, which encodes envelope proteins. (Options A, C, and D ruled out)
  • The gp120 protein produced by env is responsible for binding to the CD4 receptor and coreceptors, influences cell tropism (targeting lymphocytes or macrophages), and contains the main antigenic sites that trigger neutralizing antibody responses.
  • The gp41 product of env includes a transmembrane domain that anchors it in the viral envelope and a fusion domain that aids in the virus's entry into host cells.
  • The genetic variability in HIV's envelope proteins presents a major obstacle to creating a successful AIDS vaccine.

questions.text: A doctor working in a laboratory with HIV-1 observes that it has 11 subtypes. Gene sequences in which of the following forms the basis for this classification ?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • HIV-1 is divided into 11 subtypes based on variations in the env and gag gene
  • Among humans, there are two major types of AIDS-causing viruses: HIV-1 and HIV-2. These types are classified based on differences in genome structure and their evolutionary relationships with other primate lentiviruses. The sequence difference between HIV-1 and HIV-2 is substantial, exceeding 50%.
  • HIV-1 is further divided into four major genotypes: M (main), N, O, and P, with the M group being the most prevalent worldwide.
  • This group is subdivided into 11 clades or subtypes (A-K), identified by variations in the env and gag gene sequences. (Options A, B, and C ruled out)
  • These variations influence the antigenicity and immune recognition of proteins like gp120 and the capsid protein.
  • HIV-2, in contrast, consists of six subtypes (A-F), and shows extensive genetic variability similar to HIV-1.

questions.text: A 26-year-old presents with a weight loss of 20kgs from her initial weight of 65kgs within 3 months. She also has had intractable diarrhea within this period. She tests positive for HIV infection. Lately, she has been having visual symptoms. Upon fundoscopy, the following appearance is seen. At what CD cell count does this illness manifest?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The given clinical scenario of weight loss, diarrhea, and given fundoscopy finding of pizza pie appearance in a retropositive patient is suggestive of CMV
  • Cytomegalovirus (CMV) is a common member of the herpesvirus family and is a double-stranded DNA virus that can cause serious disease in individuals with weakened immune systems. A hallmark of CMV infection is the significant enlargement of infected cells
  • During the primary infection, cell-mediated immune responses are suppressed, which contributes to the virus's persistence and delays immune system recovery.
  • In immunocompromised patients, CMV can reactivate and lead to more severe manifestations, including pneumonia, hepatitis, colitis, or widespread infection.
  • In such patients, CMV infection, referred to as "CMV syndrome", often begins with nonspecific symptoms like fatigue, fever, loss of appetite, night sweats, general discomfort, and joint or muscle pain.
  • Respiratory involvement may present as rapid breathing, low oxygen saturation, and a dry cough, indicating pulmonary complications.
  • The gastrointestinal system may also be affected, with colitis being the most frequent form in transplant recipients. CMV can lead to ulceration in the esophagus, stomach, small intestine, or colon, which in severe cases may result in bleeding or perforation.
  • CMV retinitis is another serious complication, initially affecting one eye and often progressing to both in untreated individuals. Patients typically experience visual disturbances such as decreased vision due to macular involvement or floaters from inflammation in the vitreous. The retinal appearance is marked by dense white infiltrates in the periphery accompanied by flame-shaped hemorrhages, forming a characteristic "pizza pie" pattern along the vascular arcades.
  • Retropositive patients are at risk for opportunistic infections and the risk increases with lower CD4 counts as shown below.

Reference https://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/rr5804a1.htm

questions.text: A 40-year-old retropositive man has been non-compliant with HAART recently and now presents with focal neurological deficits, headache and 2 episodes of seizures. Upon imaging, the following lesions were observed. What is the appropriate prophylaxis against this condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The given clinical scenario of focal neurological deficits, seizures, and multiple ring enhancing lesions is suggestive of cerebral toxoplasmosis for which cotrimoxazole is used as prophylaxis.
  • Cerebral toxoplasmosis is among the most frequent causes of secondary central nervous system infections in individuals with AIDS.
  • It typically emerges as a late complication of HIV infection and primarily affects those with CD4+ T-cell counts below 200/μL.
  • The typical clinical features include fever, headache, and focal neurological deficits. Seizures are common and may be the first sign of HIV-related illness.
  • Seizures due to cerebral toxoplasmosis are often accompanied by cerebral edema, confusion, lethargy, dementia, or progression to coma.
  • On imaging, especially MRI, cerebral toxoplasmosis usually appears as multiple ring-enhancing lesions, although in some cases only one lesion may be seen.
  • These lesions typically show inflammation and central necrosis, surrounded by edema.
  • The standard treatment involves sulfadiazine and pyrimethamine with leucovorin for a duration of at least 4-6 weeks.
  • Other options include regimens with clindamycin, atovaquone, or azithromycin combined with pyrimethamine.
  • Due to frequent relapses, long-term maintenance therapy with sulfadiazine, pyrimethamine, and leucovorin is recommended for patients with a prior history of the condition, especially if their CD4+ count stays below 200/μL.
  • Patients with CD4+ counts under 100/μL and who test positive for T. gondii IgG should be started on primary prophylaxis with a single double-strength tablet of TMP-SMX (cotrimoxazole). (Options A and D ruled out)
  • Once ART is effective and the patient's CD4+ count rises above 200/μL for at least six months, prophylaxis or maintenance therapy may be discontinued.

Explanation of other options:

Clotrimazole (Option B): Belongs to the azole group of antifungals used in candidiasis and dermatophytosis.

questions.text: A 24-year-old HIV positive primipara is worried that her baby will acquire the infection during delivery. You console her that her newborn will be tested for the infection at 6 weeks. Which of the following tests will you perform first?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • In a neonate born to an HIV-infected mother, HIV DNA PCR is the investigation done at 6 weeks to detect infection in the newborn.
  • HIV can be transmitted from parent to child before birth (intrauterine), during delivery (intrapartum), or after birth (postpartum via breastfeeding).
  • Intrauterine transmission has been detected as early as 10 weeks of gestation using PCR or viral culture, but most cases likely occur in late pregnancy when placental integrity decreases, allowing maternal-fetal microtransfusions.
  • Intrapartum transmission is more common, often with no detectable virus in the infant until after the first week.
  • This likely occurs through mucosal exposure to infected genital secretions or microtransfusions during labor.
  • Breastfeeding is the least frequent mode in resource-rich countries but accounts for up to 40% of perinatal infections in resource-limited settings. Transmission risk from breastfeeding is higher during maternal primary infection and can triple in this setting.
  • Risk factors for vertical transmission include high maternal viral load at delivery, preterm birth (<34 weeks), and low antenatal CD4 count.
  • Maternal HIV antibodies cross the placenta, so infants test antibody-positive at birth regardless of infection status.
  • Most uninfected, non-breastfed infants lose these antibodies by 6-18 months and are termed seroreverters. IgG-based antibody tests cannot reliably diagnose HIV infection in children under 24 months. IgA and IgM are also of limited clinical value.
  • Definitive diagnosis in young infants requires virologic testing such as HIV DNA or RNA PCR, since these can detect infection within the first months of life. (Options A, B, and D ruled out)
  • Testing is recommended at 2-6 weeks after completing prophylaxis in high-risk newborns.
  • A confirmed HIV diagnosis requires two positive virologic results from separate samples.

questions.text: A 25-year-old patient presents with flu-like symptoms and gives a history of unprotected sexual contact a week back. Her HIV antibodies are not yet detectable. Given the clinical presentation and the timing of the exposure, what is the most reliable diagnostic test among the given options for detecting HIV during this period, before seroconversion occurs?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Based on the clinical scenario, the patient is in window period and the most reliable diagnostic test among the given options to detect HIV during this period is RT-PCR.
  • The diagnosis of HIV infection can be approached through antibody detection, virus isolation, nucleic acid or antigen detection, and resistance testing.
  • Antibody detection is the most commonly used method. However, antibodies may take 2-8 weeks or even months to appear post-infection. This period, known as the "window period," is highly infectious but seronegative.
  • Virus isolation involves culturing HIV from lymphocytes in peripheral blood, with higher viral loads seen in AIDS patients. The most sensitive method is cocultivating test samples with uninfected, stimulated peripheral blood mononuclear cells, followed by detection of viral growth via reverse transcriptase activity or p24 antigen testing.
  • While antibody-positive individuals usually have culturable viruses, the process is time-consuming, mainly used for research, and has largely been replaced by PCR techniques. (Option B ruled out)
  • Routine blood screening for HIV infection relies on detecting antibodies to HIV and/or the HIV p24 antigen. A widely used laboratory method for this purpose is the ELISA, also known as the enzyme immunoassay (EIA).
  • Positive EIA results require confirmation, typically through Western blot detection of antibodies to HIV proteins such as p24, gp41, and gp120/160, with two or more bands indicating positivity. HIV-2 requires separate Western blot confirmation. (Option D ruled out)
  • Antibody response patterns change during disease progression, with antibodies to envelope proteins persisting while anti-p24 antibodies decline.
  • Detection of viral nucleic acids or antigens includes RT-PCR, branched DNA assays, and p24 antigen detection.
  • These methods are sensitive, allow viral load monitoring, and are useful in early infant diagnosis, where maternal antibodies make serology unreliable.
  • Low-level p24 antigen can be detected early but often disappears as antibodies form, potentially reappearing late in infection. Fourth-generation assays combining antibody and p24 antigen detection shorten the window period, and fifth-generation assays can differentiate between HIV-1, HIV-2, and p24 antigen.
  • Nucleic acid testing further reduces the infectious window and is used in acute infection, occupational exposures, and donor screening.
  • HIV resistance testing identifies mutations in viral genes such as reverse transcriptase and protease that confer drug resistance. Genotypic testing is the standard, using sequencing to detect resistance-associated mutations, while phenotypic testing measures the drug concentration needed to inhibit viral replication by 50%, helping assess clinical significance. (Option C ruled out)

questions.text: A 35-year-old presented with a 7-month history of fever and chronic diarrhea. He has lost 17 kg of his body weight. He gives a history of multiple encounters of unprotected intercourse. The patient was cachectic and appeared chronically ill. His laboratory parameters are as follows: CD4 lymphocyte count of 130/uL and HIV viral load of 30,000 copies/mL plasma. At what CD4 cell count should Anti-retroviral therapy (HAART) be started in this patient?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Initiation of HAART does not depend on CD4 counts and is initiated promptly once the diagnosis is made unless the patient is also diagnosed with other infections such as those with cryptococcus or mycobacterium tuberculosis.
  • Antiretroviral therapy (ART), also called highly active antiretroviral therapy (HAART), is the primary approach to managing HIV infection and should be initiated promptly after diagnosis, except in certain situations like cryptococcal or TB meningitis where delaying ART may reduce the risk of severe immune reconstitution inflammatory syndrome (IRIS). (Options A, B, and C ruled out)
  • Current ART drugs fall into four main categories: reverse transcriptase inhibitors (nucleoside/nucleotide and nonnucleoside), protease inhibitors, integrase inhibitors, and entry inhibitors (fusion inhibitors, CCR5 antagonists, CD4 antagonists).
  • A standard initial regimen often includes two nucleoside/nucleotide reverse transcriptase inhibitors (e.g., tenofovir-based or abacavir + 3TC/FTC) plus a nonnucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitor, an integrase inhibitor, or a protease inhibitor boosted with ritonavir or cobicistat. Many fixed-dose combinations of these drugs are available.
  • Drug resistance testing should be done before starting ART and whenever therapy changes due to treatment failure.
  • While HIV-1 is the most common infection, some patients may have HIV-2. Although treatment principles are similar, certain nonnucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitors, such as efavirenz and fosamprenavir, are ineffective against HIV-2 and should not be used in ART regimens for these patients.

questions.text:
A 37-year-old presented with complaints of multiple skin lesions, respiratory complaints and abdominal distention. On examination, generalised lymphadenopathy and hepatosplenomegaly is noted and lab investigation reveals hypercalcemia. Her peripheral smear is as shown below.

Which of the following is the most likely etiological agent?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The given clinical features of fever, lymphadenopathy, hepatosplenomegaly along with the peripheral smear showing cells with flower-shaped nuclei is suggestive of adult T-cell leukemia caused by human T lymphotropic virus -1.
  • Human T-cell lymphotropic virus type 1 (HTLV-1) is a delta retrovirus linked to adult T-cell leukemia/lymphoma (ATL) and HTLV-1-associated myelopathy (HAM), and may also contribute to infective dermatitis, arthritis, uveitis, and Sjögren's syndrome.
  • HTLV-1 uses GLUT-1 as its primary receptor, aided by neuropilin-1 and heparan sulfate proteoglycans. Infected cells typically express the viral gene hbz, while the tax gene, though not binding DNA directly, promotes expression of host transcription factors, cytokines, and membrane proteins that support proliferation and transformation.
  • HTLV-1 spreads via breastfeeding, sexual contact, and contaminated blood, requiring cell-to-cell contact. ATL is more linked to perinatal transmission and HAM to sexual transmission.
  • The latency is 20-30 years for ATL and ~3.3 years for HAM.
  • ATL presents in four clinical types: acute, lymphomatous, chronic, and smoldering, among which the most common presentation is acute ATL.
  • Acute ATL accounts for roughly 60% of malignant cases and presents with a brief prodrome of about two weeks from symptom onset to diagnosis, followed by an aggressive course.
  • It typically manifests with rapidly advancing skin lesions, lung involvement, elevated calcium levels, and lymphocytosis featuring cells with lobulated or "flower-shaped" nuclei.
  • The malignant cells show monoclonal proviral integration and express CD4, CD3, and CD25 (low-affinity IL-2 receptor), with serum CD25 serving as a potential tumor marker.
  • Skin lesions may resemble those seen in mycosis fungoides, while lytic bone lesions, frequent in this condition, contain osteolytic rather than tumor cells and generally lack osteoblastic activity. Bone marrow infiltration is often patchy despite the leukemic presentation.
  • HAM is a progressive spastic paraparesis predominantly affecting women, with symptoms of leg weakness, back pain, bladder dysfunction, and sensory changes. MRI shows white matter and spinal cord lesions with CD8+ T-cell infiltration.

Explanation of other options:

HHV-8 (Option B): HHV-8 infection in immunocompetent children may present with fever and a maculopapular rash. In immunocompromised individuals, it can cause fever, splenomegaly, lymphoid hyperplasia, pancytopenia, or rapid-onset Kaposi's sarcoma, and may also lead to multicentric Castleman disease or KS-associated inflammatory cytokine syndrome.

HBV (Option C): Acute HBV infection follows an incubation period of 30-180 days and often begins with a prodrome of systemic symptoms such as anorexia, nausea, vomiting, fatigue, myalgias, and low-grade fever, with jaundice typically appearing after 1-2 weeks. During the icteric phase, patients may develop dark urine, pale stools, hepatomegaly, and right upper quadrant pain, with some cases complicated by extrahepatic manifestations like arthritis or rash.

Human T lymphotropic virus - 2 (Option D): Although first identified in a patient with a T-cell variant of hairy cell leukemia, HTLV-2 has not been definitively linked to a specific disease. However, emerging evidence suggests it may be involved in certain neurological, hematologic, and dermatologic disorders, warranting further investigation, especially in light of prior confusion about HTLV-1 and HTLV-2 prevalence in drug users.

questions.text: A known case of HIV, non-compliant to HAART presents with fresh complaints of fever, altered mental status and neck rigidity. Suspecting meningitis, CSF tap was done. India ink preparation with CSF shows the following findings. Which of the following drugs is for treatment of this condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The given clinical features along with is suggestive of cryptococcal meningitis which is managed with fluconazole.

  • Cryptococcus neoformans and gattii cause cryptococcal infection, typically acquired from environmental sources such as soil or bird droppings, with inhalation of infectious particles being the primary route.
  • The disease is a major concern in immunocompromised individuals, particularly those with HIV/AIDS, and commonly presents as meningoencephalitis, but pulmonary, skin, and systemic involvement may also occur.
  • Diagnosis relies on detecting yeast cells or cryptococcal antigen in sterile body fluids, with India ink staining revealing the capsule's clear zone.
  • In HIV-infected patients, cryptococcosis demands aggressive treatment and remains incurable without immune recovery.
  • In AIDS cases, therapy is divided into two stages: an induction phase aimed at lowering fungal burden and relieving symptoms, followed by lifelong maintenance to prevent relapse.
  • Pulmonary or extrapulmonary disease without CNS involvement is managed with fluconazole. Severe disease may require adding flucytosine for 10 weeks before continuing lifelong fluconazole.
  • For CNS involvement, the preferred induction regimen is amphotericin B plus flucytosine for two weeks, then fluconazole for at least 10 weeks, followed by lifelong maintenance with fluconazole.

Explanation of other options:

Cotrimoxazole (Option A): Used in HIV patients for Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia (PCP) prophylaxis and treatment. Not effective against Cryptococcus neoformans.

Griseofulvin (Option C): Antifungal effective against dermatophytes (tinea, ringworm infections). Not useful for systemic fungal infections like cryptococcosis.

Continue HAART only (Option D): HAART is important in HIV management but not a treatment for active cryptococcal meningitis. Immediate antifungal therapy is lifesaving; HAART may be reintroduced later to avoid immune reconstitution syndrome (IRIS).

At the time of diagnosis and then yearly thereafter

questions.text: What is the optimal schedule for CD4 count measurement in a patient diagnosed with HIV infection?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The optimal schedule for CD4 count measurement in a patient diagnosed with HIV infection is at the time of diagnosis and then every 3-6 months.
  • Laboratory monitoring in HIV infection integrates clinical and laboratory information to optimize patient management.
  • A strong correlation exists between HIV-related symptoms and CD4+ T-cell counts, making these counts a standard part of evaluation.
  • Sensitive assays developed after the discovery of HIV allow quantification of viral RNA, enabling monitoring of disease progression and treatment response.
  • CD4+ T-cell counts reflect current immune status and guide prophylaxis decisions, with counts <200/µL indicating high risk for Pneumocystis jirovecii, and counts <50/µL indicating risk for MAC.
  • Regular monitoring is recommended from diagnosis every 3-6 months, with adjustments based on stability and treatment duration. (Options A, B, and C ruled out)
  • HIV RNA quantification, usually by RT-PCR, measures viral load with high sensitivity, detecting as few as 40 copies/mL.
  • Monitoring intervals vary depending on treatment phase, with more frequent testing early in therapy and every 3-6 months once stable.
  • Viral load trends help evaluate immune system activation, replication, and resistance development.
  • Other tests which can be done after diagnosis of HIV include resistance testing to detect resistance against anti-retroviral drugs and co-receptor tropism assays.

choices.text: It is a side effect of HAART

questions.text: A patient with advanced HIV starts antiretroviral therapy (ART) and, after a few weeks, presents with exaggerated symptoms of previously controlled opportunistic infections. What could be the underlying mechanism driving this sudden worsening of symptoms following the initiation of treatment?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The given clinical scenario of paradoxical worsening of previously controlled opportunistic infections after initiation of anti-retroviral therapy is consistent with Immune Reconstitution Inflammatory Syndrome (IRIS) which is due to recovery of the immune system.
  • Immune Reconstitution Inflammatory Syndrome (IRIS) occurs after starting effective ART, leading to a paradoxical worsening of untreated, partially treated, or preexisting opportunistic infections, as well as possible flare-ups or emergence of autoimmune conditions.
  • When linked to a known infection or neoplasm, it is termed paradoxical IRIS, while cases revealing a previously undiagnosed condition are called unmasking IRIS.
  • The term immune reconstitution disease (IRD) is sometimes used to differentiate infection-related IRIS from autoimmune-related manifestations.
  • IRIS is particularly frequent in untreated mycobacterial or fungal infections and appears after ART initiation, especially in those starting treatment with CD4+ counts below 50 cells/µL and experiencing a rapid drop in HIV RNA.
  • Symptoms can develop within 2 weeks to 2 years and may include localized lymphadenitis, prolonged fever, pulmonary infiltrates, hepatitis, increased intracranial pressure, uveitis, sarcoidosis, and Graves' disease.
  • The course can be prolonged, and severe cases may be fatal. The mechanism resembles type IV hypersensitivity reactions, reflecting rapid immune recovery as HIV RNA declines and immunosuppression resolves. (Options A, B, and C ruled out)
  • In severe presentations, glucocorticoids may be needed to reduce inflammation while antimicrobial therapy is given.

questions.text: Which regimen is considered the preferred first-line treatment for a 5-year-old patient with body weight 18 kg receiving Highly Active Antiretroviral Therapy (HAART) for HIV?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The preferred first-line treatment for a 5-year-old patient with body weight 18 kg receiving Highly Active Antiretroviral Therapy (HAART) for HIV is Abacavir-Lamivudine-Lopinavir/Ritonavir.
  • The national guidelines for managing HIV in children advise using a first-line regimen that combines zidovudine or abacavir with lamivudine, along with either a protease inhibitor or an integrase inhibitor.

questions.text: An intern while drawing blood samples during emergency duty mistakenly injures himself. The patient is later found to be HIV positive. Till what maximum period should he be started on Postexposure prophylaxis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The maximum duration until which postexposure prophylaxis against HIV can be started after a needlestick injury is 72 hours.
  • Postexposure prophylaxis (PEP) is an important HIV prevention strategy, used for healthcare workers after needlestick or body fluid exposures, and also following a single high-risk incident such as unprotected sex, high-risk sexual assault, or intravenous drug use/needle sharing.
  • It should be initiated as quickly as possible, ideally within 24 hours, and no later than 72 hours after exposure, with earlier administration offering greater effectiveness. (Options A, B and C ruled out)
  • Baseline investigations should be performed when starting PEP, but treatment should not be delayed while awaiting results. Initial testing includes a fourth-generation HIV antigen/antibody ELISA, hepatitis B and C screening (unless the individual is already immune to hepatitis B through vaccination), serum creatinine, and alanine aminotransferase (ALT).
  • For sexual exposures, tests for gonorrhea, chlamydia, and syphilis should also be performed. After completing the PEP course, follow-up testing is advised at 4-6 weeks and 3 months post-exposure, with an additional HIV test at 6 months if hepatitis C infection occurred, as HIV seroconversion may be delayed in co-infection.
  • PEP involves a three-drug regimen taken for 28 days. In those aged 12 years or older, the preferred regimen is tenofovir DF plus emtricitabine, combined with either dolutegravir (once-daily) or raltegravir.

choices.text: Follicular dendritic cells in the tonsils

questions.text: HIV primarily infects cells through interaction with CD4+ receptors. However, certain cell types can be affected by HIV in a way that does not require CD4+ T cell interaction. Which of the following cell types can be directly affected by HIV without relying on CD4+ T cell interaction?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Among the given options, follicular dendritic cells in the tonsils can be directly affected by HIV without relying on CD4+ T cell interaction.
  • HIV preferentially infects activated CD4 T cells including those specific for HIV antigens.
  • Follciular dendritic cells are positioned within the B cell follicles and help maintain their structure through secretion of CXCL13, which attracts B cells and T follicular helper (TFH) cells.
  • FDCs capture complement-opsonized virus through the CD21 receptor, allowing HIV to persist in association with them.
  • Viral RNA has been found to co-localize with FDCs, suggesting they may act as a continuing source of infectious HIV.
  • Dendritic cells arise from bone marrow stem cells and display distinct immunophenotypic markers depending on their subtype.
  • Classical dendritic cell precursors (CD34+) give rise to DCs with markers such as CD11c and variably CD1a. Follicular dendritic cells originate from mesenchymal stem cells and are characterized by CD21, CD23, and CD35 expression.

Explanations of other options:

Glial cells (Option A) and microglia (Option B): HIV affects microglial cells in the brain by directly infecting them. These infected microglia can sometimes fuse together to form syncytia, which are large multinucleated giant cells. Although the level of viral replication in these cells is relatively low, their infection contributes to ongoing HIV presence within the brain.

Gut-associated lymphoid tissue (Option C): HIV targets the gut-associated lymphoid tissue (GALT), where it infects and destroys large populations of CD4+ T cells-primarily memory cells-through direct viral damage as well as apoptosis triggered by immune activation.

Reference:

https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC4666623/

questions.text: An infant born with HIV is found to be HIV-positive on screening at 6 weeks of age. The infant has not received any vaccinations so far. What is the appropriate timing and criteria for administering the BCG vaccine in this infant?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The appropriate time and criteria for administering the BCG vaccine in an infant born with HIV is, after ART administration and when the CD4+ count is greater than 25%.
  • Children diagnosed with HIV should not routinely receive the BCG vaccine because of the heightened risk of disseminated BCG disease.
  • However, vaccination may be given if the child is on ART, shows no clinical illness, and is immunologically stable. Stability is defined as a CD4 percentage above 25% in children under 5 years, or a CD4 count of at least 200/mm³ in those older than 5 years. (Options A, B, and D ruled out)
  • Where CD4 testing is not available, stability can be judged clinically by the absence of new opportunistic infections or other concerning signs.
  • If viral load testing is possible, an undetectable result together with the child being clinically well and free from new infections also fulfills the requirement for vaccination.

Reference:

https://tbksp.who.int/en/node/2050
